show.title: Ghost (1990)
show.headline: A love that will last forever

event.title: <show-title>Ghost (1990)</show-title>
event.headline: A classic supernatural romance film that made the world horny for pottery wheels
event.description:
“Molly, you in danger, girl.”

But then again, aren’t we all in danger at the end of the day? Despite many more pressing matters, it seems that the “danger” we often fear the most is that of loss or abandonment. How do we rebuild our lives when we’ve lost someone who shaped our existence? And how do those we’ve lost move on when they feel like they have unfinished business in this world? In Jerry Zucker’s 1990 supernatural romance film GHOST, some of these questions are asked and…kinda answered. Listen, don’t expect any huge revelations about mortality and the afterlife. This isn’t Bergman – think TWILIGHT, not THE SEVENTH SEAL. And it’s pretty damn queer!

Pretty boy Sam Wheat (Patrick Swayze) leads a charmed life with androgynous artist girlfriend Molly Jensen (Demi Moore) until a violent mugging leaves Sam dead and Molly in shambles. But there’s more – Sam is a ghost now (hence the title) and he’s determined to protect Molly from impending danger with the help of dubious medium Ode May Brown (Whoopi Goldberg). Yes, there is cross-gender body-hopping, don’t worry. Erotic pottery, a boyish hairstyle that made headlines, and an Oscar-winning performance from Goldberg turned this spectral romp into the top-grossing film of 1990. Written by queer screenwriter Bruce Joel Rubin (he also wrote JACOB'S LADDER – this dude loves metaphysics), GHOST is filled with subtextual interrogations of liminality, gender, and identity. Plus Swayze is in it, and as we’ve said before, Patrick Swayze has never made a “straight” film. Happy Valentine’s season queers. We love you! (Now you say “ditto.”)

event.title: <show-title>Hell or High Water</show-title> <event-type-title>Free Victory Screening</event-type-title>
event.headline: Presented by Ilegal Mezcal
event.description: Join us for a Free Victory Screening of HELL OR HIGH WATER, presented by Ilegal Mezcal. Guests can order from a special cocktail menu featuring three cocktails from Ilegal Mezcal. Each guest will also receive a letterpress recipe card for one of the cocktails, plus a drink ticket to use in the bar after the screening. The bar event will feature tattoo artists and live music/DJs. All you have to do to secure your seat is buy a small food and beverage voucher redeemable toward food and non-alcoholic drinks at the show.

eventType.title: Free Victory Screening

eventType.description: Calling all Victory Members! We’re saying thanks with a free screening. Just buy a food & beverage voucher to reserve your seat, and then use it toward food and drink at the show.

show.title: Game Night
show.headline: It’s all fun and games, right? RIGHT?!

event.title: <show-title>Game Night</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: It’s all fun and games, right? RIGHT?!
event.description:
GAME NIGHT takes on a whole new meaning for married couple Max (Jason Bateman) and Annie (Rachel McAdams) and their pals in this action-packed black comedy. Normally, their weekly routine wouldn’t be anything more intense than say, a round of Scrabble or charades. But this time, Max’s brother Brooks (Kyle Chandler) is on hand to up the stakes, arranging a murder mystery party complete with folks who will be posing as thugs and federal agents. Or maybe not? The suburban players start to question when things like kidnapping, guns, and bullets – especially the bullets – start to look and feel a bit too real.

Former Freaks and Geeks star-turned-filmmaker John Francis Daley (co-writer of SPIDER-MAN: HOMECOMING) co-directs the dark comedy alongside Jonathan Goldstein. Bateman and McAdams’s domestic couple are joined by co-stars Billy Magnussen (INGRID GOES WEST), Lamone Morris (TV’s New Girl), and Kylie Bunbury (TV’s Under the Dome). Also in for the fun are Jeffrey Wright (TV’s Westworld) as an FBI agent, and genre vets Danny Huston (WONDER WOMAN) and Michael C. Hall (TV’s Dexter).

Your ticket includes the following props:

  • Sewing kit
  • Hamburger dog toy
  • Dog keychain
  • Small bag of Tostitos
  • Branded plastic shopping bag

show.title: Jumanji (1995)
show.headline: Roll the dice and unleash the excitement!

event.title: <show-title>Jumanji (1995)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Roll the dice and unleash the excitement at our interactive movie party!
event.description:
Two kids get way more than they bargain for when they sit down to play a seemingly innocent jungle-themed board game. Robin Williams and eye-popping, effects-driven adventure ensue.

See, the game Jumanji is a magical one. By playing it, the two inadvertently release Alan Parrish (Robin Williams), a man who’s been trapped inside the game ever since he was a boy 26 years ago. But soon after reentering the real world, Alan is forced to play the game again. But this time, the mischievous game sets the creatures of the jungle loose on the city. Now, Alan and the kids must stop the mayhem and get those rampaging animals back in the box.

Good luck with all that, kids.

Your ticket includes the following props:

  • Animal dice
  • Custom wooden player token
  • Monkey tail
  • Branded hand drum
  • Acrylic keychain designed like the crystal ball in the center of the game board

show.title: The Phantom of the Opera (2004)

event.title: <show-title>The Phantom of the Opera (2004)</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Wear the mask and sing the songs at this interactive epic
event.description:
Take BATMAN & ROBIN director Joel Schumacher, add in Cats scribe Andrew Lloyd Webber, throw in a huge dose of opera (with just a dash of Minnie Driver), and you’ve got yourself some grand campy goodness.

Join us for THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA Movie Party, a musical extravaganza that’ll throw its magical lasso around you and never let go. We’ll have candles to illuminate the chandelier scene, roses to celebrate Christine, bracelets from the Opera Ghost (or the Angel of Music, not sure which), and, of course, your very own Phantom mask. All we ask of you is that you and your friends come ready to belt out some opera (we're sure you'll sound molto bene) as we revel in the music of the night.

show.title: Charlie's Angels (2000)
show.headline: It's Lucy Liu, our girl Drew, Cameron D, and Destiny

event.title: <show-title>Charlie's Angels (2000)</show-title>
event.headline: Diaz, Liu, and Barrymore in the reboot that launched a million queer fantasies
event.description:
“Good morning, angels!”

In the year 2000, we entered the dawn of a new age. Low-rise jeans riddled the landscape as far as the eye could see, camera phones shifted how society documented their lives, and “Oops…” Britney Spears “Did It Again” with the release of her multiplatinum second album. Amongst all these developments, music video director McG released his feature film directorial debut CHARLIE’S ANGELS. This reboot of the popular '70s television series is one of the most 2000s things ever to exist! Natalie, Dylan, and Alex (Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore, and Lucy Liu) are private investigators working for mysterious millionaire Charlie Townsend. When the trio is tasked to locate missing software developer Eric Knox, they find themselves wrapped up in a conspiracy of dizzying proportions. Vacillating between male gaze-centered cheesecake and action femme camp, CHARLIE’S ANGELS confused audiences and left them wondering who exactly the film was for. Reevaluation has reclaimed this “guilty pleasure” as a piece of sapphic gateway cinema that introduced millions to the pleasures of goofy women kicking ass and being something “a little more than friends.” Like, these women are in a polycule – there's no question of that – and their flirty relationship is the highlight of the film. Featuring absurd gravity (and logic)-defying wire work, dozens of ridiculous disguises, a bizarre performance from Crispin Glover, and a trio of leads having a blast together, CHARLIE’S ANGELS is a wild great time at the movies. See you at the cinema, angels!

show.title: Shrek
show.headline: The greatest fairy tale never told

event.title: <show-title>Shrek</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: The greatest fairy tale never told
event.description:
When a green ogre called Shrek discovers his swamp has been "swamped" with all sorts of fairytale creatures by the scheming Lord Farquaad, Shrek sets out, with a very loud donkey by his side, to persuade Farquaad to give his swamp back. Instead, a deal is made. Farquaad, who wants to become the king, sends Shrek to rescue Princess Fiona, who is waiting for her one true love. But once they head back with Fiona, it starts to become apparent that not only does Shrek like Fiona, but Fiona is keeping something secret.

Your ticket comes with the following props:

  • Ogre ears
  • Onion keychain
  • Eye-pop bird
  • Smell-along card

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: Baby Day Show
sessionAttributes.description: For our baby day shows, we keep the lights up a bit, and the sound down a bit, so your little one never has to know they even went to the movies!

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.
